text: Hi,
My name is Iwase and I'm a solution architect at AWS.
In this video, I'll introduce DynamoDB storage classes prepared according to the data characteristics they handle, and show what characteristics they have.
First, we'll introduce the storage class, and then we'll look at the explanation of how to set it up using the console as a demo
This DynamoDB Nuggets is a learning content that introduces useful content for using DynamoDB in a short video of about 15 minutes per video.
It's a short content, so I hope you feel free to watch it.
OK, let me get into the main story.
First, I'll introduce what types of storage classes are there,
Next, I will explain the characteristics of Standard-IA, which is suitable for storing data that is infrequently accessed, and how to determine usage.
Finally, we'll show you how to set it up using the console as a demonstration.Well, I'd like to move on right away.
DynamoDB provides two storage classes depending on how the data is used.
The first one is now Standard, and the second one is the Standard-IA storage class.
First, it's standard, but when you create a table in DynamoDB, this is the storage class selected by standard.
As for the second Standard-IA, this storage class has the characteristic that storage costs are reduced by up to 60% compared to Standard.
Therefore, costs are optimized when storing more data for a long time.
However, compared to Standard, the cost of manipulating data is increased by about 20%. In terms of performance, both are similar.
Therefore, it is suitable for workloads that store large amounts of data but are not frequently accessed, and may lead to cost optimization.
Key use cases include application log storage and operation logs for auditing.
In order to actually decide to use Standard, what guidelines should you base your selection on?
As an effective guideline, first of all, it is a case where storage costs significantly exceed the cost of data access in the overall cost.
In other words, it is not an effective class when there is a lot of access to small amounts of data.
The specific decision figure is when storage costs are higher than 42% of throughput costs.
Let's check it out based on specific use cases and data sizes.
For example, in the case of using application operation history during audits, etc., in the case of a data size of 1 terabyte,
$285 is reduced to $117 for Standard and Standard-IA, as shown in this table.
On the other hand, when the recruitment cost is 1 million times for lights and 10,000 leads, you can see that standard IA is higher, albeit slightly.
However, since storage costs have been drastically reduced, the overall cost is less than half.
As mentioned in the previous example, if the amount of data is large and the access frequency is not that high, you can expect a cost reduction effect of as much as 60% by using Standard-IA.
This is because Standard-IA's storage cost is around 40% of Standard's.
Up to this point, we have explained the usage guidelines and cost reduction effects of Standard-IA, but there are also points to keep in mind when using it.
This is when the access frequency is high and the amount of data stored is small.
The access cost is 1.24 times that of Standard, and the setting is low compared to the compression ratio of storage costs,
If the amount of data is small, the compression cost will also decrease, so there is a possibility that the total cost will be reversed when the number of accesses is high.
In this example, the data size is 70 gigabytes, which is small compared to the previous example,
but in contrast, the number of accesses is extremely high, 50 million times for writes and 100 million times for reads.
As a result, the cost of reducing storage costs has been outweighed by the increase in access costs.
Please keep this in mind and use it with an appropriate workload.
Now, when actually using the console to create a new table, how to select a storage class, and
and Let's take a demo of two patterns for changing the storage class of an existing table.
First, here are the steps for creating a new table.
Click Tables on the left menu.
And it's on the right.
Click Create table.
Type the table name.
I'd like to use "TestData" this time.
I would like the partition key to be a "dataid".
The sort key is not set in particular.
Then, when it comes to storage class settings, check the part called Customize table setting item settings.
This opens a field in the table class.
You can choose between 2 types: Standard and Standard-IA.
Check that it is Standard-IA.
After that, click Create table at the bottom without making any changes.
Table creation will be completed after a while.
Let's check if the storage class is what you intended.
First, click on the table name.
Then you can check the detailed information of the table.
If you open additional general information,
The table classes are displayed.
That's right, it's Standard-IA.
This completes the creation of a table using the Standard-IA storage class.
Next, let's change the storage class of the existing table.
This time, I've created a table using the Standard storage class beforehand.
This will be the default storage table.
First, check the table classes.
As before, it is displayed in additional information, and I think you can see that it is Standard.
Also, the data has been put into this table beforehand, so I'd like to check it.
